We do discounted cash flow analysis on any capital investment and I'd have to say on most of the capital expenditures that I have signed off in recent times, we have been well in excess of our hurdle rates in terms of expected returns from the investment side. I think this is good for all of the businesses and it will underpin growth in the group going forward.
Okay. Thanks a lot.
Your next question comes from the line of Grant Saligari from Credit Suisse. Please ask your question.

Hi. Thank you. If I can just start with a clarification question. The write-down because of the flood damage and then the insurance recoveries, have they all been allocated back to their respective divisions, or are they sitting somewhere else?

The amount that we provided for basically the insurance recoveries has been allocated back to the divisions and obviously, the impact that we haven't provided for in relation to further business interruption effect is obviously well-worn within the EBIT results that the businesses have produced.
The write-down of $66 million, that's in the respective divisions?
Yes.

Thank you. Second question regarding Target, just following from an earlier one. I guess – I'm just trying to understand the extent to which the additional markdown expense in the second half might have really impacted things, because the EBIT the second half on Target was $70 million, down from $100 million, the ECP, and higher than that obviously second half '09. So, any light you could shed on that would probably be helpful?

Okay. Well, as you know, we had a very disappointing November and December, but unfortunately, the stock had already been bought and there was very little we could do about it and some of it, as I said earlier on, could have probably been – we didn't do the best of buys. But there was also aggravating circumstances, particularly with the weather, where a lot of seasonal product like swimwear and beach towels, et cetera, doesn't sell due to the unseasonably cold summer.

Now that merchandise had to be marked down in January, February, and March, because it's very much our policy that we really do clean up our product. That's one of the things that we are absolutely strict about, is seasonal product needs to be marked down and cleared, so we can start the next season clean. And we have a very large proportion of our business is seasonal, because we are a fashion business.
Right, so should we interpret that delta, $100 million to $70 million as mainly markdown, or a small proportion is markdown?

Well, it's a combination of both, because we didn't get the sales, you also didn't get profit in the first half, because you are not selling the better – the product that we tend to make most of our margin on is on our seasonal product. But you have a twofold situation. If you don't sell, you don't make it and then you also end up taking markdowns as well in order to clear it. So, it's really a combination of both, but we were emphatic that we need to keep our inventory clean.
Okay. Thank you, that's helpful.
Your next question comes from the line of Craig Woolford of Citigroup. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon, guys. If I can just start off on Coles and in particular, the investment that you talk about. You talked at length about investing in price, but does the company feel that they need to invest in other areas of staffing and further above the line marketing investment?

No, we've invested in both two of those areas as well, Craig, particularly in the fresh food areas. If you're going to sell fresh food, then you've got to invest further in making sure you look after the product in-store. We developed a number of training of programs, particularly in fresh fruit and veg, which is really now in order to make sure that we look after the product more effectively and we rotate it. And we've had a full re-rostering on the front end as well to drive efficiency improvement in terms of lowering queues at the checkouts.

So, we certainly continue to invest there and we'll do again. And so, it's not just about price, it's about investing in the quality of the product as well, which we've done again through some of the programs that we identified. So, it's a program turnaround that relates to a number of different factors, not just about investing and price.

Sure, so just to be clear, I think when Wesfarmers inherited the Coles business, the wage percentage in store was quite low. Do you get the feel that service levels and all the aspects of staffing in store are now at appropriate levels?

Yeah, and there is probably more efficiency that we can take out of it as well. I think that's one of the things we've really identified was to, wasn't necessarily that the overall costs were being pared back, which indeed, they were, but it was the way in which the costs were being allocated and there was sort of an approach which is very much focused on the cash dollar remuneration as opposed to investing in the business to drive sales and look at what your cost of doing business might be and your percent of sales on remuneration overall.

So, we've actually developed a program, which enables us to track wage spend far more efficiently and effectively across each of the individual categories within a store in order to make sure that store can grow on income, but.
My second question, you'll never guess, is about CapEx. Can I just add in – can you clarify for the $2 billion that was spent in FY '11, how much related to land and buildings?

I think if you turn to slide 59, Craig, we have got land and buildings 2011 and 2010 shown up, so $642 million of that was land and building and within our forecast of $2.8 billion to $3.2 billion, that's – we obviously had an increase on $642 million baked into that forecast.

Okay, so the land and buildings is retail. The reason I'm following this issue is just the – is any of the CapEx, in some ways, being forced because property development in retailing has ground to a halt? And so effectively, Wesfarmers has to internalize that to ensure store growth continues?

I think – and I'll hand over to John, because I said a lot of this was in plannings. But I think rather that we see this as being a great opportunity for us the last couple of years and I think we have taken full advantage of it as a group.

Yeah I think it would be wrong to characterize it as a negative, Craig. There are less property developers able to purchase and then work through the development of a site. That's a fact. But actually, the market conditions are terrific for doing that. And if you go back into the '90s, the initial strength of the Bunnings warehouse network was built on taking the opportunity and taking charge and driving the acquisition and the development of a site ourself.

And we've just gone back to what's part of our DNA. Our property and construction team are really first rate and they are having a lot of fun and doing a great job. And now, we have to get back to the other side of the equation and that's the financing side of it on the other side of opening the sites. And our CFO and our Head of the Property Finance Area, we're working hard on getting good outcomes for sale and leaseback going forward, which will net this out over time.
So, this, say, the Bunnings business in particular, if you had acquired a property site, is that – the property side of that, is that a NPV positive transaction or is it negative?

We look at the underlying property condition and we want to do a property transaction that makes sense from a property developer's perspective, but we actually don't want the best property outcome. But we want the best business outcome and that is the best store for Bunnings.

So, when we do the CapEx, the CapEx is approved or not approved based on the business outcome, with an underlying glance at what it looks like from a property perspective to make sure it washes its face. And over time, as a property developer and that's a core capability of that business, we've managed to produce on the long run, around 2% to 3% of our EBIT average from property development profits. And going forward, who knows what that will be, because conditions do dictate the sort of property we're able to get. But we see a reasonable outcome around the order that I've just mentioned over the 5 to 10 years look forward.

Craig, when we do the CapEx, we use a pretty conservative assumption of what we will sell the property for down the track. So, we're not disjointed. It's based on the business justification, but we are very conservative on our assumptions of property realization, which we usually exceed.
Sure, but it's the verticals that you'll retain across the property development and the retailing that's, I assume, giving you the justification
...we weren't in control of our own destiny as much as we should have been.
Sure, thanks, guys.
Thanks, Craig.
Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Broeren of RBS. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon. Just in regards to Kmart, in regards to the poor performing categories there, barbecues, entertainment, and outdoor, I think you mentioned, Guy, is EDLP the right strategy for those products, given that they aren't staples? Will people just go and buy those product categories when they are on sale?

Maybe they – probably not. I mean, let me spill it into two different areas, because one is driven by market conditions, so that's the entertainment area. So, we are finding a significant drop in music CDs, because of the ability to download apps on the iPhone and whatnot. So, that category is really hurting us.

And the other part in the entertainment area is that what we are selling consoles for 12 months ago are about half the price. So, we are still selling similar amounts of Wiis and Xboxes, but the market price of those across all of us from David Jones to myself and the ones in between, the retail prices of those are at half, so volumes the same, but dollars are down significantly, so the market conditions on the entertainment.

On barbecue and outdoor, I think it was just one of those, whilst we were spending a lot of our time trying to get the whole EDLP model right, in particular, apparel and homeware. I think that our focus on barbecue and outdoor wasn't as strong and also garden, and we've now just about cleaned that up. So, it was a laggard in changing the model. So, we definitely – I think we definitely probably got that area right now, but it's less big and bulky and a lot more everyday use around the things that you need for the barbecue, versus having the range of barbecue, if you like. Hopefully, that helps.

Yes, that makes sense, thanks. And just the second question was on liquor and really around the small format issues that you discussed. Woolworths has continued to invest capital in new small format stores and refurbish those format stores as well, so is this small format issue a company-specific one?

And I guess just second to that, I was just interested to know why it's taken so long to realize that 1st Choice needs to be overhauled and that the liquor store network needs to be reconfigured. I would have thought both of those things would have been fundamental changes that you would've looked at from year one.

Well, I think that that we have, the structural dynamic that's happening within liquor in Australia is not dissimilar to what's happened in other markets. And essentially, you've got polarization where the smaller store format, if it's adjacent to a supermarket, is where people would buy liquor for convenience. And what's evolving is a broader level of destination style awareness through the larger box format, and we play in both of those markets.

We've had development over time of a refresher program in liquor lines since the start of the Coles turnaround and redeveloped a number of stores into a revised format there and have also enhanced it since then. The same is true on 1st Choice where a number of the stores have been developed, we've changed the format there. We've changed the interior of the store and the look and feel.

Where you're seeing the biggest challenge in liquor more generally in the marketplace is standalone small store formats, which don't kind of fit inside of those two categories and that's an industry issue, not a company one. So, overall, we're pleased with the progress that we've made in liquor, we've growing the sales overall, the market share has grown consistently over the last three years, we repositioned it in terms of its price, we've improved its overall profitability ahead of its sales and we expect to see further growth coming in the marketplace. But some of the elements in terms of structural change in relation to the portfolio will take time to change, the same as they are with supermarkets. But we do expect to see further progress down the train.
Okay. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of Michael Simotas of Deutsche Bank. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon, guys. Thanks very much. Just one for me and following on from the previous question about liquor. There's a comment you made that the sales in the liquor business have grown. Is that in reference to FY'11 and if it is, did it grow consistently through the year, or did you see the growth level fall away in the fourth quarter?

I think we've seen growth come through during the course of the year. And we've seen consistent growth coming through during the course of the three years that the turnaround has been in progress so far. Certainly when the stimulus package was on a couple of years ago, then there was a broader benefit there, but we're seeing good progress in the area of liquor within our business and I think it's been well documented as a pretty challenging market at the moment.

Okay, great, thanks. And then just a quick second question, on the Kmart business. Kmart Tyre & Auto is obviously a very different business to the department store operations. Could you perhaps just comment on how the performance between the two businesses has differed and also, what expansion plans there are for Tyre & Auto?

Yes, sure. So, there are three parts to the Kmart model, right? So, there is the Kmart Australian stores, the New Zealand Kmart business and the Kmart Tyre & Auto. Each time I've spoken about this business, Kmart Tyre & Auto has always been a very strong business, has got good sales growth, has had good EBIT growth. The most significant change that's happening in the last 12 months under John Sink's leadership is the – the just under 300 outlets that we've got are getting a considerable makeover from how they look from the outside as you drive along the streets. So, a considerable amount of reinvestment is being plugged into business similar that came out wasn't given the capital to or reinvestment to fix it up.

And also, a lot of money being spent on the customer service area, where particularly it's, again, a female-driven business similar to retail, to create a better environment, not just in the reception area, but also the receptionist, if you like. So, it's doing well and I think the – within a 24-month period, nearly every one of their stores would have been totally revamped and they look good, great model.

Michael, without putting down Guy's response, which is a very good response, and the terrific people in Kmart Tyre and Auto, it's in the group scheme of things, a pretty immaterial business, I must say. And even in Kmart, it's a handy contributor to the overall business, but that's the scale of it.
Sure. Okay, thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Greg Dring from Macquarie. Please ask your question.

Thanks. Good afternoon. Just an observation on property, Terry, and a question. So, as you are going to spend more than $642 million on land and buildings next year, you probably spent $1.7 billion over three and you've got a starting point, so there's clearly a land grab going on here. The trades are talking about Coles having a budget of $1 billion for property. If you add in Bunnings. I imagine that covers most of it. So, is that what's driving this, you guys just trying to get distribution for your brands and the other guys out there doing the same thing?

I don't know that I will classify it as a land grab. I think what we said is that the environment in Bunnings has always had a very strong property portfolio and network that has built up in the current environment, as John explained, has enabled us to accelerate and be very pleased with that position. We said Coles wasn't active enough in its own portfolio and we have been making moves to accelerate that.

The reality is, I think you said $1 billion of property allocated to Coles. Well, that's not true. So, I think what we've said is we've said $642 million in land and buildings this year, mainly in retail obviously, mainly in Bunnings, and we'd expect an acceleration on that amount and that's within the $2.8 billion and $3.2 billion forecast that we've given.

Okay. The second question is for Ian, just talking to slide 17, I'm looking at the reduction in wastage index. And the question is, is the index the movement in the percentage of wastage or perhaps the dollars saved? And in terms of the index alpha, are you above what you consider to be an acceptable level of wastage for a supermarket?

Well, I think we are getting pretty close now to levels where we'd anticipated being from our previous experience. I mean, there is still more to go in relation to improvements that we can make. But certainly on the percent of sales basis, the better performing stores are delivering new levels that we'd anticipate to see consistent with what we've seen before.
And is that index the change in the percentage of wastage or the dollars saved?
Sorry, could you ask that question again?
I was wondering what the index is on slide 17 top right hand panel? What does..
Whether it's on dollars or on percentage.
Yes, or is it the actual percentage wastage in?
Yes, I think it's on dollars, but I'll come back to you.
Okay. Thank you.
If it's any different, but I think it's dollars.
Your next question comes from the line of David Cooke of Nomura. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon, a couple of questions, start off with Ian. Ian, $800 million worth of return to customers through lower pricing. If I then backsolve on what your deflation was for the year, it suggests that you took pricing up by about $730 million in other areas. Is that concentrated in a couple of categories where you were passing through cost pressures, or is that pretty much across the board?

No, we haven't been doing that. If the implication is we've been taking prices up another line to fund the reductions, that certainly isn't what we've been doing. Essentially, what we've been doing here is driving out efficiencies through the business to create a savings pool and that's been reinvested back in price.

If you look at how the $800 million is calculated, you've got to look at where the average rate of inflation was running prior to the acquisition, which runs about 4.5% a year and then you look it earning from there to deflation of 1.6% during the course of last year, so a combination of the investment in price, which is real, and the suppression of price increases is actually where you get the number from. So, it's not a question of putting prices up in other directions.

Certainly in some categories, there has been inflation, but that's been driven by the other extraneous factors. In produce, for example, the situation in relation to bananas has been well documented, as indeed in areas like tomatoes and cucumber as well. So, we've seen in some of these fresh areas, prices move up, but in other areas, we've invested heavily. So, there has been a countervailing effect, particularly in grocery, which has meant that our underlying position has delivered deflation or inflation.

Sorry, just so that I've got this one right. The $800 million is since the acquisition and it relates to the differential between if inflation had continued at pre-acquisition levels versus minus 1.6% in....

No, it's not a question of a cumulative effect over a three-year period, it's an in-year element. If you look where inflation was running prior and where we have taken it so far and you look at the differential in terms of level of investment we've taken and what we've actually suppressed in terms of increases that we have chosen not to pass on, that's where you get the $800 million from.

Okay. If I look at the expansion of your liquor licenses or liquor stores that you're talking about over the next couple of years, how are you going to get the liquor licenses? Are you going to have to buy sites that already have liquor licenses or do you think you can apply to get that many over the next couple of years?

Well, the liquor licenses are determined by different legislations in different states. There are opportunities to expand accordingly. Certainly, it's becoming more challenging to get liquor licenses as we move through, but there are opportunities to move liquor licenses where we might move a small store to a larger store in a similar catchment.

Okay. Just a quick one for Launa and Guy. If I look at your inventory levels respectively in Target and Kmart going into July, are you comfortable with them, or because June sales were as poor as they're reported to have been, does that mean you've got an inventory hangover and you're having to do markdowns to clear that inventory?
Okay, Guy, do you want to answer first?
Not really. I think Adam and Teresa are okay, I think it was David, right?
Yeah.
If you could get a message onto the front pages of the papers around Australia to come and visit our stores at our lowest price, that would be great. That would help, but they are generally okay.

Okay, with regards to us, we actually consciously needed a little bit more winter because we were light on the end of June last year, but we are exactly we want to be in with regards to week's cover versus the same time as last year. So, we are actually comfortable with them.
Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of David Errington of Merrill Lynch. Please ask your question.

Oh, we're going around again, thanks. Richard and Terry, one of the great – the businesses I'm concerned about is Gresham, particularly the private equity. Now, I do understand that it's noncash and it's priced to book, et cetera, et cetera, but over the last four years for the Gresham Private Equity Fund business, you've made a profit of $16 million in '08, you lost $57 million in '09, you made $43 million in '10 and you've dusted $60 million in '11.

Over the four years, you've lost $60 million and you've probably invested about $300 million or $400 million into that business. I just don't get the Gresham Private Equity Fund business. I just don't understand what Wesfarmers is doing there. I understand that Wesfarmers has got an inter-company connection with Gresham. There is some corporate governance issues there that I don't particularly like, but that's a discussion for another day. I just think that that four-year history has now shown that this business really shouldn't be in the makeup of Wesfarmers and I just don't understand why it's there and I'd like you to comment on that.

Yes, David. Just on the corporate governance side of things, we own 50% of Gresham and we've invested in Funds One, Two, and Three. And Fund One, the realized investments grew out of the significant profit for the group and in Fund Two, the only realized investment, I think, which is the nappies business, which has been a very good cash realization for us as well. So, there's a difference between what's been reported and what we've realized and we'll realize in the future. But clearly, the last year or two...
Wouldn't that be in there, Richard? I mean, you've basically – that's the outcome of that, if you realize it, that would be in those numbers, wouldn't it?

Yes. It is, although Fund One is probably prior to that. And then as Terry said, the movement this year is basically a carrying value movement and it's a compression of PE ratios on potential exists and the challenges in some of the businesses, so I'm not resigning from that. But the bottom line on this, David, will be, will we make adjacent return on the investment? I think the internal rate of return we made on Fund One was high 20% and time will tell on Fund Two. Fund Three hasn't made any significant investments at this stage. And in terms of our sort of what we've currently got invested, Terry, help me out, but it's not hundreds of millions of dollars. I would think it's in the tens of millions of dollars.
Yeah, a bit more than that.
You've lost $60 million, it'd have to be a fair bit more than that, wouldn't it?
Sorry. Speak up a bit?
If you've lost $60 million this year, you'd have to have a fair bit invested for the book value to move that much.

Yes. We've got in funds, really, there is a not a lot invested. We made a commitment, but as Richard said, there hasn't been a lot of investments in Fund Two. It's broadly around $100 million and it effectively is similar to its carrying value at the moment or thereabouts, so.
In Fund One?
And Fund One might have made significant profits.
It's been fully realized.
Okay.

So, David, it's to date based on our realizations, the investments in Fund two is more challenging, where we are involved, we don't sit back, Terry and I and Tim Bult are on the investment committee. And yeah there is still – there are some good investments in Fund Two. The issue shall be whether they can be properly realized, things like Barminco and there is one or two other things that look reasonably prospective at the moment, but time will tell.

Second question, Richard. I'm listening to Guy talking about taking more inventory on through direct sourcing and it's a trend that other retailers are doing. I'm just a bit concerned that taking on more inventory risk – I mean, I do understand that you take on more inventory risk, it does lower the cost, you get lower cost et cetera. But if you get it to bounce around in economic conditions, you can be left with pretty heavy inventory risk and the inventory increase this year of $450 million or so, I'm just a bit concerned about the trend that this is going.

Yeah, on the direct selling, there is couple of things there. Terry talked a bit about the key part of that, which was Coles. On the direct side of things, David, you are right to point it out. There is a potential risk. I think we manage it pretty well. You certainly get a margin expansion through doing it.

And we don't sit on inventory now, and Target will come out, if we are all concerned about it, we deal with it pretty effectively and we keep a very close eye on this through the management teams in the business and then through the other side that we have here. So, and in fact, I think the supply chain, the length of the supply chain, if you like, is compacting, not extending as we do this. So, the risk diminishes through having more efficient and direct supply chain.

There are probably competitors, Richard, which I suppose we take with a pinch of salt, but I would like you to comment on it for the record, that a couple of signs at Kmart in particular, it's low cost strategy is predicated pretty much on just buying loads and loads of inventory and it's sitting on container loads of inventory in docks all around Australia. Can you quash that for the record?

Yeah, I actually had those ships sitting off ports full of Kmart gear. We know exactly what the inventory is, we know what they're holding. And we have got some significant benefits in Kmart through better buying, there is no question about that. And Guy has talked a bit about that at the results, sorry, the strategy day in July, but we don't have containers and containers sitting around the place.
Have you got too much inventory in Kmart, Richard?
Oh, we've got a little bit more than we'd probably like at the moment. But that's, Guy, maybe $10 million, nothing more than that.

David, on – this is Terry here. In the segment notes, the second section, you can see the assets employed from 2010 to 2011 and you can look at – do a bit of work to strip out capital expenditure and depreciation and it gives you a fair idea what inventory may have moved.

So, in terms of what the movement's been in Kmart, yes, there has been an increase in inventory, but you'll be able to work out yourself, it's not material relative to the inventory increase in total for the group, which we have said is when you work that through, Bunnings is obviously opening up a lot of stores and growing sales. But you've got to look at the creditor side of that as well, because obviously, you get funding on that.

And similarly, Coles is growing and in Coles we are taking more into, they say, fresh, like milk and chips, which is obviously gives us advantages and competitive advantages and we are going to go through a very significant change to our supply chain in Coles and you would be mad not to watch the customer and make sure you look after the customer, while increasing safety stock ahead of that. So, I think I wouldn't get overly concerned about Kmart's inventory position when you look at the group's inventory growth.
Thanks, Richard, thanks, Terry.
Thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Phil Kimber of Goldman Sachs. Please ask your question.

Just wanted a clarification on the chemical, energy and fertilizer business. You gave some numbers of shutdown and LPG impact on the fiscal '12 profit, is your starting point the adjusted $241 million this year, or is it the reported $283 million that we should be reducing by?
